node.title: How a Central Otago farm became Montana for The Power of the Dog - and the region's film hopes
node.description: Dame Jane Campion's The Power of the Dog has become a critical darling, and with the Central Otago-filmed movie up for awards, it has inspired pride and hopes for the region.

node.title: Covid-19 update: Four deaths, 10,239 cases, 848 in hospital
node.description: Four further deaths of people with Covid-19 have been reported in New Zealand, with the number of confirmed cases dropping to 10,239 today.

node.title: Unfriendly fire and plaudits as govt dismantles Covid-19 measures
node.description: Week in Politics: The Prime Minister announces a significant easing of Covid-19 restrictions - but she doesn't please everyone - and New Zealand offers non-lethal military aid to Ukraine.

node.title: 2022 Oscars: Red carpet, awards, speeches and more live updates
node.description: The show will be hosted by Regina Hall, Amy Schumer and Wanda Sykes.

node.title: China-Solomons security deal 'very concerning' if true - Mahuta
node.description: The Foreign Minister says New Zealand's High Commissioner will speaking to the Solomons government, "and we will also be raising our concerns directly with China".

node.title: Woman who died in Gisborne named
node.description: Maraea Marata Smith turned 36 on Friday - the same day she was found dead on Titoki Street after police were called to reports of a fight.

node.title: East Coast flooding: 'It’s extremely tough' - PM
node.description: After talking to locals in Tokomaru Bay today, the prime minister says repairing roads and supporting locals with insurance issues will be priorities as the region cleans up from the week's flooding.

node.title: Carter leaving White Ferns
node.description: The White Ferns coach Bob Carter is stepping down from the role after New Zealand failed to make the Cricket World Cup semifinals.

node.title: Kinzinger "not convinced" Meadows has given all texts to January 6 committee
node.description: Kinzinger, one of two Republican members on the House select committee investigating January 6, said he's "not convinced" Meadows has turned over all messages relevant to the probe.

node.title: Oscars 2022: Full list of nominees and winners
node.description: "The Power of the Dog" leads the pack with 12 nominations followed closely by "Dune," which picked up 10 of its own.

node.title: Transcript: Marie Yovanovitch on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Marie Yovanovitch, former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, that aired Sunday, March 27, 2022, on "Face the Nation."

node.title: Transcript: David Martin and Michael Morell on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with CBS News national security correspondent David Martin and former Acting CIA Director Michael Morell that aired Sunday, March 27, 2022, on "Face the Nation."

node.title: Today's sports news: What you need to know
node.description: In today's sports news - Windies on verge of series win, Phoenix snatch last-gasp win and SVG gets second win of Supercars season.

node.title: Transcript: Bob Woodward and Robert Costa on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Bob Woodward and Robert Costa that aired Sunday, March 27, 2022, on "Face the Nation."

node.title: Transcript: Will Hurd on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with former Rep. Will Hurd that aired Sunday, March 27, 2022, on "Face the Nation."

node.title: South Dakota House to decide whether state AG should face impeachment
node.description: The committee has been probing whether Jason Ravnsborg should be impeached for conduct surrounding fatal car crash in 2020.

node.title: Transcript: Rep. Adam Kinzinger on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with GOP Rep. Adam Kinzinger of Illinois that aired Sunday, March 27, 2022, on "Face the Nation."

node.title: Syrian eyewitness details crimes against humanity
node.description: "I know what Russia has done in Ukraine — what it can do — because I know what it's done in Syria," he said.

node.title: Oscars 2022: David Edelstein asks, "Why does this thing still exist?"
node.description: Everyone, it seems, is angry at the Academy Awards, and for many reasons - which, says our film critic, might make this year's Oscar ceremony the most freakishly riveting yet. Check out his predictions.

node.title: Jim Gaffigan's advice to parents of young kids: It only gets worse
node.description: After years of standup in which he's complained about his five young children, the comedian and "Sunday Morning" commentator has discovered something truly terrifying: being the father of five older children.

node.title: "The Godfather" at 50: The making of a classic
node.description: Francis Ford Coppola, Robert Duvall, James Caan and Talia Shire recall the making of the Hollywood classic about a mob family that forever changed how we look at movies.

node.title: Buster Keaton, the "Great Stone Face"
node.description: The silent-film star, writer and director of some of the greatest comedy films ever made, whose artistic ingenuity, stunts, and innovations inspire filmmakers to this day, is now the subject of two new biographies and an upcoming film.

node.title: Douglas Brinkley on Madeleine Albright, a "Hammer of Democracy"
node.description: The historian remembers the trailblazing Secretary of State and U.N. Ambassador, who promoted NATO enlargement while antagonizing despots around the world.

node.title: Lin-Manuel Miranda to miss Oscars after wife tests positive for COVID
node.description: Lin-Manuel Miranda, one of this year's most prominent Oscar nominees, will sit out the ceremony after his wife tested positive for COVID-19.

node.title: Diving into the debate over trans athletes
node.description: The success of UPenn swimmer Lia Thomas, a transgender woman, has reignited a fierce debate: do trans women have an unfair biological advantage in sports? And are competitive fairness and trans inclusivity mutually exclusive?

node.title: Meet a Russian oligarch hit by sanctions
node.description: Mikhail Fridman, a Ukrainian-born Russian oligarch living in London, explains why he believes sanctions - which are blocking his accounts, even his ATM card - are not the answer to punishing Russia's leader Vladimir Putin.

node.title: Where museum guards pick the art
node.description: At the Baltimore Museum of Art, a new show, "Guarding the Art," was organized not by the museum's curators, but by its security staff – people who spend more time with the art on the walls than anyone else, but are rarely asked for their opinions.

node.title: Almanac: The 1952 premiere of "Singin' in the Rain"
node.description: Seventy years ago, the film regarded as perhaps the greatest Hollywood musical ever – a Technicolor love letter to Hollywood starring Gene Kelly and Debbie Reynolds – debuted.

node.title: Breaking through Russia's digital Iron Curtain
node.description: Inaugurated during the Cold War, Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty broadcasts news to countries where freedom of the press is under assault – and with Russia shutting down independent news sources, its mission is even more critical.

node.title: Another Russian quagmire: Putin and the shadow of Afghanistan
node.description: In 1979 the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan to install a puppet regime; they were defeated after a 10-year fight against rebels armed by the CIA. Now, the Kremlin's failure to install a puppet government in Ukraine has exposed weaknesses in its military.
